text: <@U04UDN6BY|madhurtewani> has joined the channel
<@U04UDV7JJ|minwoo> has joined the channel
<@U04V2A679|hsiangmin> has joined the channel

So <@U04TK850N> just to wrap things up and to understand it; a ContentProvider communicates with the DB. The Adapters fetch data from the ContentProvider and in my activities I call to a Adapter to retrieve data?
Basically. You just connect the adapter to to the cursor returned by your content provider
The ContentProvider encapsulates the CRUD operations into a defined interface you talk to

Other thing I dont really understand the fact of returning a Cursor object from a Adapter. I have a 'getAll' method in my CompanyAdapter which return data from the ContentProvider as a Cursor object. So I can add the Cursor to the ListView. Im really used to returning data in Models..
Where would the logic be to insert retriever data into a Model?
You can do the same. If you e.g. return an ArrayList<MyModel> you can e.g. use an ArrayAdapter :wink:
You can just write some helper methods for that. Query the provider, iterate over the cursor, return an array of models, use that to fill the listview
Just make sure you do that stuff async since DB operations might take a while and block your UI thread depending on the complexity if you do it there
With LoaderManager and its LoaderCallbacks you get that for free

In our app I use both, usually the cursor since I can freely configure my projections and selections on demand, but for retrieving a single object, I have helper methods to build it. Which runs in an AsyncTask though as it might take a while
Ooh okay
<@U04UEGMR4|sammybuoy> has joined the channel
Great! Thx for clearing up
So my Adapter hs tonextend asyntask?
No, your adapter extends one of the suitable adapter classes
The adapter runs on the UI thread since it fills the UI :smile:
I need help in writing the unit test case. I want to unit test the flow where a activity loads a fragment which makes a network call and updates the UI. I have created a restclient using a retrofit.
I'm not an expert on UnitTests, sorry :confused:
Ok.. thanks
So its a Adapter extending an AsyncAdapter?
There is no AsyncAdapter. There is e.g. SimpleCursorAdapter if you go with the cursor approach, or ArrayAdapter if you go with the model aproach
The already get the data from you

Lets go with the cursor example. You let your Fragment implement the LoaderManager.LoaderCallback interface. You at some point start the query to your ContentProvider. Then you'll get a callback once your data is ready, that will give you a Cursor with your data. Then you tell the Adapter to use this cursor and it will build the Views or tell you to build them in its callbacks
And the is for the ArrayAdapter?
Give this a read, it should explain that pretty well: <https://github.com/codepath/android_guides/wiki/Using-an-ArrayAdapter-with-ListView>

attachments.title: codepath/android_guides
attachments.text: android_guides - Extensive Open-Source Guides for Android Developers

text: Only difference is, that you get your data from your ContentProvider, not from JSON. So you would at one point query your provider, build your models from it, fill the adapter and let it build the listview
Okay thx
Will take a look at it!
<@U04UF3DMC|ewnd9> has joined the channel

hi there
<@U04V44RL9|bob> has joined the channel
Hi. i have a pojo with some optional fields , what is the best method to handle this?
I just read the article you provided me <@U04TK850N>. Great explanation, I think I’ll just go with the ArrayAdapters for this basic app :wink:
What are the best practices for retrieving the ArrayLists with Models? I’m used to “Repositories” not sure if that’s the same in the Android world :stuck_out_tongue_winking_eye:
So I would have a `CompanyRepository` which contains `all()`, `find()` methods etc to get data from the ContentProvider
Well querying the provider will give you a Cursor anyway, so you iterate over it and create a model object in each iteration, adding that to your list and returning it when you're done
yup, but you don’t do that in the Activity itself right?
So what would that class be called when the logic is from creating the models from a Cursor object

I usually do it like this:
```
HCContentProvider: The ContentProvider itself with the CRUD operations
HCContentProviderWrapper: Helper to translate Cursors into Models and Models into ContentProviderOperations.
HCDatabase: Handles the actual SQLite access, opening/closing the database, upgrade, creation...
HCDBContract: The contract I share with the clients. Has Authority, URIs, Column definitions...
HCDBSchema: This holds the table declarations in the form of a map, mapping column names to data types and a method to generate CREATE TABLE statements from these definitions. Makes it more reliable and easier to extend.
```
oops
There you go :smile:
HC... is just a prefix I used for the last project
The nice thing is, that pattern and the sources are easily reusable. One could also write a simple generator for this
Okay and what do you mean with the ‘clients’ in the `HCDBContract`?
So for my example, I got two apps which are connected to the same ContentProvider
There is one already tho: <https://github.com/BoD/android-contentprovider-generator>

attachments.title: BoD/android-contentprovider-generator
attachments.text: android-contentprovider-generator - A small tool to generate an Android ContentProvider.

text: I would have the Contract in both of the apps  or something?
Client would be anyone wanting to access the ContentProvider
yep
Okay
Contract classes are standard all around in Android, see: <http://developer.android.com/reference/android/provider/ContactsContract.html>
There is one for calendar too

That’s nice, thanks
I might be a bit over engineering for a school assignment, but I guess it's good to learn this topic all around from the beginning :smile:
You might want to tailor to your needs tho :wink:

<@U04UQ2BD8|mholtzer> has joined the channel
"get data from contentprovider android” doesn’t give me something good
most things do have ContentProviders in the same app
So how would I communicate with a external ContentProvider
basically the same way, getContentResolver().query, just using an URI for a remote contentprovider rather than your own
I got it yeah ;D
Still got some struggles with it
It returns a NULL value
query returns null instead of a valid cursor, or calling something on the cursor returns null?
null returned from query probably means your uri is incorrect (or maybe you don’t have permission but i think that throws a securityexception)
My ProvierClient returns NULL
```ContentProviderClient cProvider = context.getContentResolver().acquireContentProviderClient(DBContract.Company.CONTENT_URI);```
The Provider is on another project
oh i’ve never used ContentProviderClient, i just use query
oh content providers might not be exported by default
in your app that includes the provider make sure you have             android:exported=“true” in the <provider part of the manifest
yup I got that ;(

```<provider
                android:name="com.example.liam.database.DataProvider"
                android:authorities="com.example.liam.database.DataProvider"
                android:readPermission="android.permission.permRead"
                android:writePermission="android.permission.permWrite"
                android:exported="true">
        </provider>```
This are the settings in the application with the provider
Does the location on the system make a difference?

that looks fine. permissions can be annoying for non-system apps, it’s install order dependent. but i think you get a SecurityException if that’s the issue (and the fix is uninstall both apps and then install the provider that declares the permission first, and the app that requests it second)
wel it’s a local
wait, maybe I have to run the app with the ContentProvider first…?

Hi All, Quick question. I’m not a developer but I manage some and build enterprise apps. What’s the best way to test your app on real devices? I find that emulators don’t necessarily reflect the real devices.
<@U04V25VKT>: we have test teams with actual devices, lots of different versions and other characteristics like screen size. But we're a big company too...

<@U04TK850N>: thanks for the response. But what if we’re smaller and can’t afford that… :confused: is there any real solution out there? I’m also based in Asia where there are tons of local “flavours” and !
*manufactures!
There are some services who offer remote device testing. But you have to script the actual testcases so they can run automatically
Sony still has their own remote test lab: <https://remotedevicelab.sonymobile.com/>
See maybe <https://appthwack.com/devicelab>

Hey I created the ActionBar using this :-

getSupportActionBar().setDisplayOptions(android.support.v7.app.ActionBar.DISPLAY_SHOW_CUSTOM);
        getSupportActionBar().setCustomView(R.layout.action_bar_custom);
this provides me what i need ,but i also need a back button on this.
Does your custom view have to fill the whole action bar?
now
NO
Then don't let your layout fill it and you'll get the default back button

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<LinearLayout xmlns:android="http://schemas.android.com/apk/res/android"
    android:layout_width="match_parent"
    android:layout_height="wrap_content"
    android:layout_gravity="center"
    android:orientation="vertical">

<TextView
    android:id="@+id/ActionBarTitle"
    android:layout_width="wrap_content"
    android:layout_height="wrap_content"
    android:layout_gravity="center"
    android:text="PAGE DETAILS"
    android:textColor="#939393"
    android:textSize="16sp" />
</LinearLayout>
this is what i am inflating
I guess you just want a centered title?

Keep just the wrap_content textview

<@U04TK850N|langerhans> uploaded a file: <https://androidchat.slack.com/files/langerhans/F04UYM1MA/Cenetred_ActionBar_title.java|Cenetred ActionBar title>

file.name: Cenetred_ActionBar_title.java
file.title: Cenetred ActionBar title
file.preview_highlight:
public void setupActionbar() {
	if (getSupportActionBar() != null) {
		ActionBar actionBar = getSupportActionBar();
		actionBar.setDisplayShowCustomEnabled(true);
		actionBar.setDisplayShowHomeEnabled(true);
		actionBar.setDisplayHomeAsUpEnabled(true);
		actionBar.setDisplayShowTitleEnabled(false);
​
		Toolbar toolbar = (Toolbar) findViewById(R.id.main_toolbar);
		View v = LayoutInflater.from(this).inflate(R.layout.actionbar_centered, toolbar, false);

    android:layout_height="wrap_content"
    android:layout_gravity="center_horizontal"
